subsc: Vocational training,Micro- and SME finance,Other industry,Central government administration
trustfund:
TF021120-SWISS CONSULTANT TRUST FUND FOR
            DEVELOPING COUNTRIES

abstracts.cdata!:
The overall outcome of the project is
            rated as satisfactory. Only 4 of 40 small sub-projects
            experienced repayment problems, accounting for less than 2
            percent of the APEX line of credit. These are the key
            lessons learned: Where macroeconomic conditions unfavorable
            to private investment exist, project objectives should be
            modified to reflect the need to create a favorable
            macroeconomic, legal, institutional environment. When
            several institutions are involved in project implementation,
            adequate mechanisms should be established to ensure proper
            coordination between them. Both the supply and demand sides
            of "the products" offered by the project, as well
            as the interest of the intermediary institutions to deliver
            them should be carefully assessed during appraisal. In this
            case, the demand for credit among the existing entrepreneurs
            was unknown and the willingness and ability of the
            commercial banking system to disburse the APEX line of
            credit was also not known. Also, when the design of a
            project includes intermediaries whose contribution is
            critical to the success of the project (in this case, the
            commercial banks were the intermediaries between the
            Government and the beneficiaries), the project should
            provide these intermediaries with strong incentives. Lastly,
            to encourage industrial development, the government should
            have an ongoing dialogue with the financial and industrial
            sectors to identify the remaining constraints to industrial
            growth and to eliminate them.
